item.title: HTML Example
item.subtitle: This uses JavaScript, too!
item.description:
There are all kinds of super fun things you can do with HTML in your XML files.
You can use http://htmledit.squarefree.com to preview your HTML. Then you can use Notepad++ to condense it all into one line easily. Just select all the text and press Ctrl+J for Join Lines in Notepad++. (It's also in the Edit menu under Line Operations.)

Hey, what day is it??




If you want to link to websites within your app, you can add target=_blank to your URL links and change the AppSettings.cs file to allow for it. By default, it is disabled.

It's also helpful to know that you can use Excel to edit your XML files, but you don't have to. Sometimes Excel just gets in the way and it'd be easier to use something like Notepad++ to edit the code directly. But you have to remember that things need to be converted first. Use this website to convert things:
https://sites.google.com/site/infivivek/resourse-centre/online-resources/html-to-xml-converter
But if you do use Excel, make sure you copy all the HTML into the one line for the description. It might help to double-click the cell and then paste it.

Also, you can make your own RSS feeds for your website, even free Google sites. Then you can write up your own XML file to upload (much like this file) using this guide:
http://www.w3schools.com/rss/rss_tag_image.asp
If you use your own RSS feed, make sure there is an image somewhere in the HTML in the description (even if it's at the bottom of the page), and it'll show up in your app (both on the main page and the sub page).

You can even make tables. And center them.
Column 1 Column 2
Row 1 abcde
Row 2 fghij


Or you can click here to order Dominos pizza. If you leave default settings on, you'll be ordering the pizza from within the app, but if you change AppSettings.cs like mentioned earlier, it'll open a new window. Or you could just call them at (713) 747-3800.

...and this is just the beginning. What else can you think of to do?


If you find an image you like online, you can right-click and copy the URL and also view the image info to see the pixel dimensions--all without downloading it.
